landing_page.ai_goal: Get user to submit their first article/news item

slides.title: Get Featured in Local News

content.headline: How to Get Featured in Local News

expectations.outcome: A publishable news item about your business

content.myth_bust: You don't need to be 'newsworthy.' You just need a story worth sharing.

slides.narration: Here's something most business owners don't realize: getting featured in local news isn't hard. You don't need a publicist. You don't need a major announcement. You just need a story worth sharing—and every business has one. In the next fifteen minutes, I'm going to show you exactly how to create news content that gets published.

slides.title: What Counts as News

content.headline: What Actually Gets Published

news_types.examples: Your story, why you started, customer stories
New products, services, team members, changes

content.insight: Local news needs local content. You ARE the content they're looking for.

slides.narration: First, let's talk about what actually gets published. Business milestones—your anniversary, an expansion, an award. Community involvement—charity work, sponsorships, partnerships. Expert insights—tips and knowledge from your industry. Human interest—your story, why you started, customer stories. And announcements—new products, services, team members. Local news needs local content. You are exactly what they're looking for.

slides.title: Step 1: Choose Your Angle

content.headline: Step 1: Pick One Story
prompts: What's new at your business right now?
What anniversary or milestone is coming up?
What do you know that would help your community?
What's your origin story—why did you start?
What's a customer success story you could share?
content.tip: Don't overthink it. The first idea that comes to mind is usually good enough.
content.action: Write down your topic in one sentence.

slides.narration: Step one: pick one story. Ask yourself: What's new at your business right now? What milestone is coming up? What do you know that would help people? What's your origin story? What's a customer success story? Don't overthink it. The first idea that comes to mind is usually the right one. Write it down in one sentence. That's your topic.

slides.title: Step 2: Use the Template

content.headline: Step 2: Fill in the Template

template_structure.headline: What's the one thing you want people to know?
template_structure.lead: Who, what, when, where, why in 2-3 sentences
template_structure.body: The details, the story, the quotes

content.tip: Write like you're telling a friend. Conversational beats formal.

slides.narration: Step two: use our template. Start with your headline—what's the one thing you want people to know? Then your lead paragraph—who, what, when, where, why in two to three sentences. Then the body—the details, the story, include a quote if you can. And finally, what should readers do next? Aim for 300 to 500 words. That's plenty. And write like you're telling a friend—conversational beats formal.

slides.title: Real Examples

examples.headline: Martinez Bakery Celebrates 25 Years on Main Street
examples.lead: What started as a family dream in 1999 has become a community institution...

examples.headline: 5 Things Every Homeowner Should Check Before Winter
examples.lead: Local contractor shares the maintenance checklist that prevents costly repairs...

examples.headline: Local Gym Raises $10,000 for Youth Sports
examples.lead: Members and staff came together for the annual fitness challenge...

slides.narration: Here's what good articles look like. An anniversary piece: 'Martinez Bakery Celebrates 25 Years on Main Street.' An expert tips piece: 'Five Things Every Homeowner Should Check Before Winter.' A community piece: 'Local Gym Raises $10,000 for Youth Sports.' See how simple these are? They're not fancy. They're just clear stories about real businesses doing real things.

slides.title: Step 3: Add a Photo

content.headline: Step 3: Add One Good Photo
photo_tips: Show people—your team, your customers, yourself
Show action—someone doing something, not just posing
Phone photos are fine—don't overthink it
content.no_photo: Don't have a photo? We can use your logo or skip it for now.
content.caption: Write a simple caption: who's in it, what's happening

slides.narration: Step three: add a photo. Articles with photos get way more engagement. Show people—your team, customers, yourself. Show action if you can—someone doing something beats everyone just posing. Natural light looks better than flash. Horizontal orientation works best for web. And phone photos are totally fine—don't overthink it. Write a simple caption saying who's in it and what's happening.

slides.title: Step 4: Submit for Review

content.headline: Step 4: Submit and We Handle the Rest

process.desc: Our editors check for typos and clarity

content.guarantee: We'll work with you to make it publish-ready. No rejections, just collaboration.
content.cost: Free to submit. Free to publish.

slides.narration: Step four: submit and we handle the rest. When you're ready, click submit. Our editors review it for typos and clarity—we're not judging, we're polishing. Your article goes live within 24 to 48 hours. Then we promote it through our newsletter and social channels. And here's the key: we don't reject submissions. We work with you to make it publish-ready. It's free to submit, free to publish.

slides.title: Start Your Article
slides.narration: Ready to get featured in local news? Click 'Start Your Article' and you'll get our guided template—just fill in the blanks. We have templates for anniversaries, expert tips, community stories, and announcements. Pick the one that fits your story. About fifteen minutes to write, and then you're in the news. Your community is waiting to hear from you.

[Quote from owner]

[Call to action: Visit, celebrate with us, etc.]
